metadata.case_name: Mohammad Umar Shaikh v. K. Kadlaskar

facts.text: Election of councillors to the Sangli City Municipality was held on June 3, 1967 under the Maharashtra Municipalities Act, 1965.
Counting of votes for Ward No. 25 took place on June 4, 1967.
Results published in Official Gazette on June 15, 1967 (and also June 8, 1967 publication noted).
Election petition filed on June 24, 1967 by petitioner K. Kadlaskar, a candidate from Ward No. 25, challenging election of appellant Mohammad Umar Shaikh.
Petition alleged appellant published undated pamphlet with untrue, false, defamatory statements about petitioner, arousing religious sentiments of Muslim voters.
Petition alleged another defamatory pamphlet dated May 30, 1967.
Petition alleged charges of terrorising voters and securing votes by false personation.
Appellant denied responsibility for publication of impugned pamphlets in written statement.
Four issues framed; first issue: whether petitioner proved opponent No. 1 used malpractices by arousing religious sentiments and making defamatory statements via pamphlets.
Petitioner gave evidence himself; appellant examined himself to contradict.
Petitioner listed witnesses Hakim Abdul Rahiman Shaikh and Gopal Chintaman Ghugare; they attended but not examined initially.
On August 21, 1968, petitioner applied for summons for these two witnesses; Judge rejected.
Appellant's case closed August 21, 1968; arguments started August 22, 1968.
On August 22, 1968, court adjourned to August 24, 1968 to record evidence of the two witnesses as court witnesses, issued summonses.
Two witnesses examined on August 24, 1968 as court witnesses; arguments resumed and concluded.
Lower court judgment on August 30, 1968 allowed election petition, held in favour of petitioner on first issue, found appellant guilty of corrupt practice, disqualified for 5 years.
Appellant filed writ under Arts. 226/227 in Bombay High Court; dismissed in limine on October 4, 1968.

Undated pamphlet contents: defamatory statements about K. Kadlaskar, ostracized from Muslim community, mismanagement of Kabarasthan, turned into brothel, illicit liquor, etc., signed by six persons including Ramjan Mohiddin Jamadar, etc.
Petitioner claimed he came across first pamphlet during distribution process.
Appellant denied publication and distribution.
Witness Gopal Chintaman Ghugare: saw people reading pamphlet but did not know distributor.
Witness Hakim Abdul Rahiman Shaikh: received copy on June 2, 1967; at prayer meeting, appellant read pamphlet, Moulana Hannan supported.

legal_issues.text: Whether procedure adopted by trial court was wrong in examining two cited witnesses as court witnesses after initially refusing summons.
Whether election petition filed beyond 10-day limit under s.21(1) of the Act.
Whether first issue was confusing and misleading, vitiating fair trial.
Whether there was no evidence of corrupt practice attributable to appellant.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant published undated and dated May 30 pamphlets with defamatory statements arousing religious sentiments, terrorised voters, false personation.

respondent_arguments.text: Denied publication and distribution of pamphlets; repelled charges of malpractices.
Procedure wrong: witnesses cited by petitioner, summons refused on Aug 21, then examined as court witnesses - irregularity vitiating trial.
Petition time-barred: filed June 24, beyond 10 days from June 8 Gazette publication.
First issue confusing/misleading, no fair trial.
No evidence of corrupt practice by appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Judge had wider powers under s.21(7) Maharashtra Municipalities Act to summon suo motu any material witness, beyond O.16 r.14 CPC; no irregularity in examining as court witnesses after initial refusal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act gives powers wider than CPC; no prejudice as no rebuttal opportunity requested.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant accepted June 15 Gazette date in written statement; precluded from raising limitation based on June 8; no error apparent for High Court intervention under Arts.226/227.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unconditional acceptance in paras 1-2 of petition.

court_reasoning.text: Issues unsatisfactory but appellant knew points to meet; evidence adduced on both sides; trial not vitiated.
Evidence, though meagre, sufficient; accepted witness testimony linking appellant to distribution; pamphlet contents defamatory and arousing religious sentiments.
5-year disqualification appropriate given serious nature; within maximum 6 years.

holdings.text: Trial court had jurisdiction to examine witnesses as court witnesses under s.21(7) of Act.
Petition within time; no interference under Arts.226/227 warranted.
Sufficient evidence of corrupt practice by appellant via pamphlet distribution arousing religious sentiments.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. Seshadri v. G. Vasanta Pai
precedents_cited.relevance: Court has wide powers to summon witnesses in corrupt practice cases even under Representation of the People Act; applicable by analogy.

statutes_cited.name: Maharashtra Municipalities Act, 1965
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribes 10-day limit for petition from result publication; gives Judge powers of civil court including suo motu summoning of witnesses.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court dismissed writ in limine; no error apparent or transgression for certiorari or superintendence.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers to examine court witnesses; Act gives wider powers.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Judge deemed civil court within meaning for trial.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; lower court order upheld finding appellant guilty of corrupt practice by distributing defamatory pamphlet arousing religious sentiments, disqualifying him for 5 years from municipal elections.

key_quotes.text: "the Judge may summon suo motu any person whose evidence appears to him to be material."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights wide powers under s.21(7) Maharashtra Municipalities Act justifying court witnesses.

key_quotes.text: "powers of the court in this respect are of wide amplitude, specially when investigation is being made into allegations about the commission of a corrupt practice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Seshadri case, upholding summoning in corrupt practice inquiries.

key_quotes.text: Appeal fails but in the circumstances of this case, we make no order as to costs.
key_quotes.speaker: court
